719983f-a.title: Manhattan: Gansevoort Street - Hudson Street
719983f-a.text:
Gansevoort Street, south side, east from and including Hudson Street.
Gansevoort Street, originally the western end of Southampton Road,
in Sir Peter Warren's farm, was later known as Great Kills Road.
As it crossed the northern end of Greenwich Lane (Sady Hill Road),
it was made part of Greenwich Lane (now Greenwich Avenue) early in
the 19th Century. Later (in the 1830's) it was closed east of
13th Street at the upper end of Asylum Street (upper West 4th
Street), and named Gansevoort Street.
The nine-story building at West 4th Street is the Riker Hegeman
Building.
July 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
719983f-a.folder: Gansevoort Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY

719981f-a.title: Manhattan: Gansevoort Street - Hudson Street
719981f-a.text:

15 to 1 Gansevoort Street, from Hudson Street to 13th Street at th
northern end of West 4th (formerly Aaylum) Street. The history

view of the south side, July 7, 1933. No. 15, at the left, is t
south side of the Trio Building (o52-o64 Hudson Street). The
houses in the background are 319 to 309 West 13th Street, on the
north side.
May 27, 1930.
L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, at a later date. Note the absence of the 4-story str
shown in No. 1 that bore Nos. 13 and 11-5-1 Gansevoort Street (also
and 340-330 West 13th Street). A more extensive view appears of th
buildings that are on the north side of West 13th Street, between H
Street and Eighth Ave. They are, from left to right, Nos. 325 to 3
April 17, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

720589f-a.title: Manhattan: Hudson Street - Gansevoort Street
720589f-a.text:
Hudson Street, south from and including Gansevoort Street (formerly
Greenwich Lane, East-West portion).
July 30, 1932..
P. L. Sperr.
